scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Information
scopecontent.p: This collection consists of two letters sent to members of the Preston Family of Abingdon, Virginia. The first three-page letter, July 25, 1791, is from William Russell, North Garden, to Captain Francis Preston, Montgomery County, Virginia, who thanks Preston for helping his son proceed on to his business in Richmond, mentions searching for horses which apparently had zigzagged up the New River, and expresses thankfulness that peace has been restored between the United States and the Cherokees through the signing of the Holston Treaty on July 2, 1791. Russell describes the terms of the treaty, which made the Cherokee- United States boundary the watershed between the Little River and the Little Tennessee River, in great detail in his letter. He also informs Preston that some inhabitants down the river are dissatisfied with the treaty because they fall within the Indian lands.

The second four-page letter, April 26, 1834, is from C.C. Lee, Spring Camp, [Christiansburg], to Mrs. Sarah Buchanan Preston, Abingdon, explains the reasons for his political defeat in the recent election in Floyd, Virginia. Lee was accused of indulging in a wild bacchanal with young girls atop Buffalo Mountain on Easter Sunday, of being a "nullifier" because he mentioned in his speech the spirit and patriotism of some of the men supporting the "Carolina doctrines," of being a bank man because he did not support "the experiment" and would not support Andrew Jackson's administration "right or wrong." Lee also mentions that Governor Floyd gave a speech at the election but feared that "the mysteries of state sovereignty & the banking system found no catching place on the bumpless pericraniums of our bumpkins."
